qas.question: What was the name of the mechanical computer that used automation?
What did the Predictor calculate after it was pointed at a target?
How did the Predictor display the information needed?

answers.text: as a pointer mounted on the gun

qas.question: What two things did the operators of the gun have to do?

answers.text: followed the pointer and loaded the shells

qas.question: What other country designed similar systems to the Predictor?

context: The solution was automation, in the form of a mechanical computer, <a0_0>the Kerrison Predictor<a0_0/>. Operators kept it pointed at the target, and the Predictor then calculated <a1_0>the proper aim point automatically<a1_0/> and displayed it <a2_0>as a pointer mounted on the gun<a2_0/>. The gun operators simply <a3_0>followed the pointer and loaded the shells<a3_0/>. The Kerrison was fairly simple, but it pointed the way to future generations that incorporated radar, first for ranging and later for tracking. Similar predictor systems were introduced by <a4_0>Germany<a4_0/> during the war, also adding radar ranging as the war progressed.
